DataElement.preferredName: PET Isotope Injection Time Dose Assay Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The quantity of a substance (such as a radioisotope) at the time of injection measured in milliCuries (mCi).

DataElementConcept.preferredName: PET Isotope Injection Time Dose Assay
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered._Substances having the same number of protons in their nuclei and hence having the same atomic number, but differing in the number of neutrons and therefore, in the mass number._Use of a syringe and needle to push fluids or drugs into the body; often called a "shot."_the continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past._A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time._The determination of the amount of a particular constituent of a mixture or of the biological or pharmacological potency of a drug.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.:Substances having the same number of protons in their nuclei and hence having the same atomic number, but differing in the number of neutrons and therefore, in the mass number.

Concepts.definition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.
A form of a chemical element containing a specific number of neutrons and a specific atomic mass.

Property.preferredDefinition: Use of a syringe and needle to push fluids or drugs into the body; often called a "shot.":the continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.:A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time. :The determination of the amount of a particular constituent of a mixture or of the biological or pharmacological potency of a drug.

Concepts.definition: Administration of a drug into a location within the body; this can be achieved either through an established access or via a needle.
The continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.
A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time.
A qualitative or quantitative analysis performed to determine the amount of a particular constituent in a sample or the biological or pharmacological properties of a drug.

A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time.
